source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Visual examination (Fig. 8) of specimens after irradiation with UV shows a "bull's-eye" of enhanced oxidation corresponding to the highly focussed beam from the Xenon arc-lamp

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: With increasing irradiation time, the maximum oxide thickness at the center of the bull'seye increases, and the bull's-eye itself broadens

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: This increase in peak oxide thickness appears to reach a limit at ${ \sim } 7 0 0 ~ \mathrm { n m }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Examination of the irradiated area with dark-field illumination also shows that any areas of enhanced oxidation appear grey (Fig. 9), an indication of porosity at the oxide surface

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: the weight gain data (Fig. 10), where the specimens with the irradiated area limited by a slot in the platinum counterelectrode reach a limiting value much earlier than specimens where the lateral growth of the irradiated bull's-eye was not so limited

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: UV irradiation at $4 0 ~ V$ in LiOH

evidence_span: Measurements of the oxide impedance in-situ have confirmed that the first phenomenon to occur after the start of irradiation with UV is an apparent thinning of the oxide (Fig. 12)

evidence_span: the peak oxide thickness indicated by impedance measurements with Viking LS232 contacts is about $7 0 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$

evidence_span: about twice the thickness of $\sim 3 5 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$ indicated by the interference colors

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Oxides formed in ATR (Fig. 15) showed clear evidence of the presence of porosity in the oxide films

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk4

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: Internal hydriding of Zircaloy cladding is a persistent cause of cladding failures

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: It occurs in the fuel rods of water-cooled nuclear power reactors that have a small cladding defect

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: Irradiation test data on the different types of defected fuel rods, intentionally fabricated defected and in-pile operationally defected rods, are compared

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: Significant factors affecting internal hydriding in defected Zircaloy-clad fuel rods (defect hole size, internal and external sources of hydrogen, Zircaloy cladding surface properties, nickel alloy contamination of Zircaloy, the effect of heat flux, and fluence) are discussed

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: Zircaloys. hydrogen pickup, zirconium hydrides, defected fuel rods, secondary hydriding

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: The hydriding characteristics of Zircaloy tubing are of interest to reactor designers because of the widespread use of Zircaloy cladding for oxide-pelleted fuel rods in water-cooled nuclear power reactors

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: Internal hydriding of the Zircaloy cladding was a persistent cause of defects and occasional failures in early commercial fuel rods

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: Two types of hydriding, external hydriding produced by hydrogen outside the fuel rod and internal hydriding from causes inside the fuel rod, were identified in Zircaloy-clad fuel rods

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: Internal hydriding is further classified as primary or secondary hydriding

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: Primary hydriding is generated internally in an initially undefected Zircaloy fuel rod

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: Its sources are hydrogenous contaminants (moisture, oil, grease, and so forth) introduced into the fuel rod during fabrication as well as any residual hydrogen in the oxide fuel resulting from the
